>One particular code smell I encounter frequently is when JUnit suites 
>ha=
ve lots (or any) System.out.println() statements. That normally 
>indicates=
 someone is trying to get more data out of JUnit tests than 
>they're reall=
y intended to produce. It's even worse if these statements 
>print when the=
 tests are passing as well as failing. In this case, 
>actual failures are =
likely to get swamped by the usual output and may 
>well not be noticed, es=
pecially when running from Ant or the 
>textui.TestRunner so there's no red=
 bar. Honestly I think the standard 
>Ant JUnit task produces too much outp=
ut already. I only want to see 
>tests that failed. I want line of output a=
t most if all tests passed.
>
>-- 
>Elliotte Rusty Harold  elharo@metalab.u=
nc.edu


I appreciate the recent comments to my post, you all have given me=
 good food
for thought, and I am coming around to the "test everything repr=
oducibly"
point of view.

I confess that I have some System.out.println() s=
tatements in my test cases.
Partly it is to see which random cases were gen=
erated, and I see the point
that I shouldn't have to scan the output.  Howe=
ver, at least I'm sure the
tests are running the way I think they should be=
 running!  I distrust
computers and software greatly, so I'm always trying =
to check up on what I
think is going on... this is doubly true when I'm usi=
ng new (for me)
software like Junit.

How do you Junit veterans assure your=
self that a test is actually running
and doing what it should be doing?

--=
ErikN
